items.title: radb.net not returning CIDR data anymore
items.body:
Looks like https://www.radb.net/ won't return CIDR lists for an AS-query anymore. Since the code in this library is written fully on that and alternate source needs to be used. For example https://ipinfo.io/ does return CIDR-lists.

I don't know if anybody else either needs CIDR-lists by ASN or is working on this one, but since my application depends on getting CIDR information, I am working on adding ipinfo.io as a data source.

items.title: Remove deprecated functions
items.body: Remove deprecated functions from prior to 1.0.0.

items.title: Update version, changes, generate docs for 1.1.0 release
items.body: Update version, changes, generate docs for 1.1.0 release

items.title: Remove deprecated disallow_permutations from ipwhois_cli.py
items.body: Remove deprecated disallow_permutations from ipwhois_cli.py. allow_permutations is set by reversing whatever --disallow_permutations is set to. This makes allow_permutations by default true, which will cause deprecation warnings.

items.title: Remove support for Python 2.6 and 3.3, add support for 3.7
items.body: Python 2.6 and 3.3 are no longer supported. Remove tests and support for these versions. Add support for 3.7.

items.title: ASN HTTP parser fails due to incorrect order
items.body: ARIN now returns the HTTP ASN data reversed. The parser fails when it does not find a valid org on the first item. Reversing the results works, but I will also need to build in a mechanism to not fail until all items are checked.

items.title: :bug: Empty ASNOrigin Lookup
items.body:
* Python version: 3.6.6 and ipwhois: 1.0.0

Code Example
```
net = Net('2001:43f8:7b0::')
obj = ASNOrigin(net)
results = obj.lookup(asn='AS37578')
pprint(results)

{
"nets": [],
"query": "AS37578",
"raw": None
}
```

Tried this for multipe ip addresses and asns , none of them return any routes. 

Tracked the issues in asn:get_nets_radb(), seems to be ipwhois response now breaks the regex.

items.title: All errors use Exception as a base class, preventing succinct error handling
items.body:
# Problem
Because all of your exceptions inherit directly from the Exception class, it's impossible to write a small exception handler for your library. As it stands, I'm forced to either handle each exception explicitly or catch `Exception` directly -- both of which are undesirable. 

I suggest something like this:
```python

class IPWhoisException(Exception):
    pass


class NetError(IPWhoisException):
    """
    An Exception for when a parameter provided is not an instance of
    ipwhois.net.Net.
    """


class IPDefinedError(IPWhoisException):
    """
    An Exception for when the IP is defined (does not need to be resolved).
    """

# ... etc ...
```

Which would then allow me to do this:

```python

try:
    # ipwhois lookup
except IPWhoisException:
    # handle it
```

Thanks

items.title: Unexpected HTTP 301 (redirect) related failures for some IPs

items.title: How are RDAP lookup and IP ASN lookup different in regards to retrieving ASN?

milestone.description: Bump from beta to stable release

items.body:
The documentation for ipwhois says that IPWhois.lookup_rdap() is now the recommended lookup method, so I assumed this was the only way to get the correct ASN. I also notice there's separate IP ASN lookup functionality. On the Linux machines where I use ipwhois, I noticed that ASN lookups are much faster with the IP ASN lookup functionality than with RDAP. However, there are a number of IPs where the ASN returned is different between the two methods. For example, for the following IPs, these were the results:

- 223.100.157.219:
    - RDAP: 56044
    - ASN lookup: 9808
- 119.141.24.44:
    - RDAP: 134772
    - ASN lookup: 4134

How are these two methods different? Which one correctly returns the current ASN? I'm using version 0.15.1 of ipwhois, Python version 2.7.

Off-topic question: Is there a contact where I can send questions like this in the future? I didn't see any on the Contributing page.

items.title: IPv6 Reserved Network Constants may be wrong.
items.body:
The set of IPv6 networks listed as reserved networks in the constants of ipaddress.py seem incorrect.

For instance, when I look at a random IPv6 I generated (caec:cec6:c4ef:bb7b:1a78:d055:216d:3a78), the result of

print(ipv6_is_defined('caec:cec6:c4ef:bb7b:1a78:d055:216d:3a78'))

is this:

(True, 'Reserved', 'RFC 4291')

I believe this is because C000::/3 is listed as a reserved network in the IPv6Constants class. I looked at RFC 4291 and RFC 7346 (which updates RFC 4291) and Wikipedia's page on reserved networks, and I don't see anything about C000::/3 being reserved. Most networks in "_reserved_networks" also don't show up in these places. Is there something I'm missing?

I'm using Python version 2.7.10 with ipwhois version 0.15.1. Here are pages I'm referencing on IPv6 reserved networks:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserved_IP_addresses
https://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4291.txt
https://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc7346.txt

items.title: Roles missing from objects queried using depth parameter
items.body:
Python version: Python 3.4.3
ipwhois Version: 0.14.0

I am attempting to get role information at depth for RDAP queries, but the roles are only ever filled in for the first level. Examples with the entirely random example IP `12.3.4.5` -

**Example 1**
```
import ipwhois
from pprint import pprint
ip = ipwhois.IPWhois("12.3.4.5")
result = ip.lookup_rdap()
pprint(result)
```
(See [ex_1_result.txt](https://github.com/secynic/ipwhois/files/753252/ex_1_result.txt), roles are included for `ATTW`. See also [ex_1_debug.txt](https://github.com/secynic/ipwhois/files/753272/ex_1_debug.txt))

**Example 2**
```
import ipwhois
from pprint import pprint
ip = ipwhois.IPWhois("12.3.4.5")
result = ip.lookup_rdap(depth=1)
pprint(result)
```
(See [ex_2_result.txt](https://github.com/secynic/ipwhois/files/753256/ex_2_result.txt), roles are included for `ATTW` again, but missing for all other entities. See also [ex_2_debug.txt](https://github.com/secynic/ipwhois/files/753273/ex_2_debug.txt))

**Example 3**
```
wget http://rdap.arin.net/registry/ip/12.3.4.5
```
(see [ex_3_result.txt](https://github.com/secynic/ipwhois/files/753279/ex_3_result.txt), roles are included for all entities.)

Based on the debug output, it seems that the role information is available in the initial query but is not used when `depth` == 0 and ignored or overwritten when `depth` > 0.

I am not sure if this is by design or if I am otherwise misunderstanding the configuration and expected output here. It is interesting that the results of `wget http://rdap.arin.net/registry/ip/12.3.4.5`, for example, actually include a number of entities and their associated information that is all removed or ignored when `depth` == 0. This seems to make sense, but why not include the basic information since it is already there?

I haven't dug in to the code at all, but I would be happy to do a PR if there is interest in tweaking this functionality.

items.title: Deprecate asn_alts/allow_permutations in favor of new argument: asn_methods

milestone.description: Bump from beta to stable release

items.body:
asn_alts in asn.IPASN.lookup(), asn.ASNOrigin.lookup(), and ipwhois.IPWhois.lookup*() has a static first lookup method (DNS for IPASN, WHOIS for ASNOrigin). 

Deprecate asn_alts and add a new argument 'methods'. This will be an ordered list of ALL lookup methods, so you can skip the initial DNS/WHOIS attempts if needed.

The new 0.15.0 class ASNOrigin was designed this way for the sake of consistency until deprecated in IPASN and IPWhois.

items.title: Move ASN parsing from net.Net to new class asn.IPASN
items.body:
Parsing should be removed from the following, and only return the raw result like the other functions in net.Net:

- net.Net.get_asn_dns()
- net.Net.get_asn_whois()
- net.Net.get_asn_http()

Other changes:

- Move net.Net.lookup_asn() to asn.IPASN.lookup() and add inc_raw argument
- Create _parse_fields_dns(), _parse_fields_whois(), _parse_fields_http() in asn.IPASN
- Change ipwhois.IPWhois.lookup_whois() and ipwhois.IPWhois.lookup_rdap() to use asn.IPASN
- Update tests

Labelling this as both a bug and enhancement as net.Net.lookup_asn() always returns a response of None at position 1 of the tuple.

items.title: query rate limit exceeded failures can cause RecursionError failures
items.body:
I recently upgraded to python 3.5 and reinstalled the ipwhois package. That upgraded my ipwhois package from 0.10.1 to 0.13.0. I'm now seeing these failures:

```
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded in comparison
```

Specifically,

```
  File "/Users/krader/conda/envs/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ipwhois/ipwhois.py", line 146, in lookup_whois
    ignore_referral_errors, asn_data, field_list
  File "/Users/krader/conda/envs/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ipwhois/whois.py", line 552, in lookup
    extra_blacklist=extra_blacklist)
  File "/Users/krader/conda/envs/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ipwhois/net.py", line 573, in get_whois
    extra_blacklist)
  File "/Users/krader/conda/envs/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ipwhois/net.py", line 573, in get_whois
    extra_blacklist)
... etcetera ...
```

The problem is that 'Query rate limit exceeded' errors call `self.get_whois()` recursively without decrementing `retry_count` as happens for socket level exceptions.

items.body:
Rate limit handling needed for Net.get_http_json(). Lacnic is set to 10 queries per minute. Need to test others.

This can be accomplished by checking the json output 'notices' which looks like this for lacnic:
`"notices" : [ {
    "title" : "Rate Limit Notice",
    "description" : [ "Rate Limit is maxed at 10 queries per 1 minutes." ]
  }]`

A new parameter will also need to be added for setting the timeout.

items.title: cymru is down, ipwhois permutation causes ourself to get blacklisted
items.body:
o_o

we need a flag in Net() to avoid permutations.

CYMRU DNS is currently offline. because DNS is yielding timeout errors, lookup_asn() is retrying via other methods -- which gets us blacklisted (stalled lookups leading to timeouts) from the other services -- which now yields several minutes per each lookup before finally giving up.

we need to pass a use_dns_only to the ASN lookup so if cymru is down, we don't punish ourselves by quickly getting blacklisted due to trying alternate means of obtaining results.

items.title: Add parsing support for organizations, roles, people, etc.
items.body:
Whois results, specifically the REST services, provide many organizations, roles, and person information. This data is currently not being parsed.

Pending analysis of common traits from each of the RIRs to create a new standard dictionary result for this data. Initial research indicates that some of this will result in additional queries per IP. For those cases, there may be a parameter for whether to pull that data or just provide a link.

I will update this thread with additional information as research progresses.

items.title: Add support for KRNIC and JPNIC servers
items.body: KRNIC and JPNIC are subsets of the APNIC database. CYMRU has all of their information refered to whois.apnic.com. Querying whois.apnic.com returns a generic response for the KRNIC and JPNIC databases. Examples: `whois 133.1.2.3` and `whois 115.1.2.3` versus `whois -h whois.apnic.com 133.1.2.3` and `whois -h whois.apnic.com 115.1.2.3`.

items.title: Support for ipaddress module for python 2.6/2.7
items.body:
There exists an ipaddress module for python 2.6/2.7 for porting the python 3.3 api: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ipaddress

When it is installed ipwhois uses it and converts the IP to str (for eg. in ipwhois/utils.py line 148) which in python 3 is a unicode object but in python 2 a byte object.
This results in an exception:

`AddressValueError: '12.34.56.78' (len 15 != 4) is not permitted as an IPv4 address (did you pass in a bytes instead of a unicode object?)`

items.title: Multi-line descriptions fail to parse properly
items.body:
The WHOIS entry for 83.248.94.149 contains these lines:

```
[...]
netname:        COMHEM-CUSTOMER
descr:          Com Hem customer broadband access
descr:          G
descr:          ISP
descr:          ********************************
                Abuse & intrusion reports should be done online at:
                http://www.comhem.se/portal/comhem/kundservice_abuse
                ********************************
country:        SE
[...]
```

`ipwhois` parses this to the description `"********************************\nCom Hem customer broadband access\nG\nISP"`.

This is wrong for two reasons:
1. The order of the lines is wrong (the stars should be at the end).
2. The multi-line descr that starts and ends with stars is not parsed properly.
